text: Newsletter question - what’s best practice for a newsletter header? What makes a good newsletter header?* What do we think about big, quite long newsletter headers vs. shorter newsletter headers? Also, should they change with every newsletter or remain the same? I don’t think I need to say but for the avoidance of doubt, I’m talking about an email newsletter haha :slightly_smiling_face: TIA!

elements.text: one thing you can do is zoom out by expanding the min/max values on the y axis

text: Hi. Since more and more people view newsletters on mobile, I think your header should not be too long that it takes up multiple lines.   As for changing header each time, it depends what you offer. If you have amazing content that every subscriber loves and looks forward to, then maybe same header is fine. But for the other 99% of us, people need a compelling reason to open and read every time. You are only as valuable as your last email :slightly_smiling_face:. If the header doesn't give them a reason to read, they have plenty of other things to do.

But for the other 99% of us, people need a compelling reason to open and read every time. You are only as valuable as your last email
. If the header doesn't give them a reason to read, they have plenty of other things to do.

text:
Do any of y'all have strong opinions about removing the date from blogs? It doesn't seem to affect SEO and everything I read online is like ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ ...but it still seems like everyone has dates.
Has anyone had experience removing the date?

elements.text:
Do any of y'all have strong opinions about removing the date from blogs? It doesn't seem to affect SEO and everything I read online is like ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ ...but it still seems like everyone has dates.
Has anyone had experience removing the date?

text: Do you mean not having dates on your posts going forward or going into your existing posts and removing the dates?

elements.text: Do you mean not having dates on your posts going forward or going into your existing posts and removing the dates?

text:
Both. Removing the date field from displaying on the blog.
The context is - our sales team uses some of our older blogs but don't want to show that they are older. I know the ideal here is updating those blogs but this seems potentially like an easier solution.

elements.text:
Both. Removing the date field from displaying on the blog.
The context is - our sales team uses some of our older blogs but don't want to show that they are older. I know the ideal here is updating those blogs but this seems potentially like an easier solution.

text: yeah this affects evergreen content because you don’t want to inadvertently make it seem like old info. it’s probably valuable for news-related content where freshness matters

elements.text: yeah this affects evergreen content because you don’t want to inadvertently make it seem like old info. it’s probably valuable for news-related content where freshness matters

text:
For user point of view, in some cases like yours, hiding a date can solve sales guys problem.

But having a date on blog affects.

Rather hiding it, only display last update date instead of published date. It may solve your problem.

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?

text: Ideal for most sites: no dates in URL, and use last modified date on the post if you use one, instead of the first published date.

elements.text: Ideal for most sites: no dates in URL, and use last modified date on the post if you use one, instead of the first published date.

text: This is just my 2 cents on this. If it's designed to be evergreen then it doesn't need a date in my opinion. If it's like a best of 2021/2022 or directed to a certain time of year or etc. then I feel it needs a date and can be updated accordingly.

elements.text: This is just my 2 cents on this. If it's designed to be evergreen then it doesn't need a date in my opinion. If it's like a best of 2021/2022 or directed to a certain time of year or etc. then I feel it needs a date and can be updated accordingly.

text: Dates are an important signal for assessing relevancy.

elements.text: Dates are an important signal for assessing relevancy.

text: I’ll note that if you remove it, you may want to keep it in the metadata of the post at least so you can more easily do analytics work with it. Especially when conducting content audits.

elements.text: I’ll note that if you remove it, you may want to keep it in the metadata of the post at least so you can more easily do analytics work with it. Especially when conducting content audits.

text: We don't have dates in the URL so that's not an issue. Whenever I update a blog, I change the published date - this issue is that this content hasn't been updated in several years and is still relevant.

elements.text: We don't have dates in the URL so that's not an issue. Whenever I update a blog, I change the published date - this issue is that this content hasn't been updated in several years and is still relevant.

text: I think, more specifically - is there anyone who has removed dates entirely from your B2B blog and how did that process go?

elements.text: I think, more specifically - is there anyone who has removed dates entirely from your B2B blog and how did that process go?

text:
Is there a way to build an option to hide or show the date at the post level? I often choose whether or not to click on an article based on a date, if Google shows one (even if the info doesn't seem super relevant to the date it was written). But if you could have a simple on/off toggle, that would solve the issue you're referring to without removing it entirely.

Edited to add: I once tried an experiment removing all the dates from posts sitewide. It was a DISASTER. This wasn't SaaS, so it's not apples to apples, but we found that including the last updated date (even an older one) seemed to impact SEO better than having no date or using the original published date OR than using original publish date + last updated date.

elements.text:

But if you could have a simple on/off toggle, that would solve the issue you're referring to without removing it entirely.

Edited to add: I once tried an experiment removing all the dates from posts sitewide. It was a DISASTER. This wasn't SaaS, so it's not apples to apples, but we found that including the last updated date (even an older one) seemed to impact SEO better than having no date or using the original published date OR than using original publish date + last updated date.

text:
<@U024K88ECFN> - Yeah, you can add them via meta data without having them visible on the front end. 

`meta property=”article:published_time”`

elements.text: - Yeah, you can add them via meta data without having them visible on the front end.
meta property=”article:published_time”
